section.title: Uniform Interface
section.para: All interaction with Resources follow a uniform interface with a defined set of method semantics

listitem.para: Returns a list of all methods supported for a specified resource
Create a new resource. Also used to tunnel other communications.
Requests a representation for a specified resource. This method should only read information and have no other impact.
Acts identical to GET except to only return metadata and not the representation.
Updates the representation of a specified resource. Can create new resources when updating a collection resource.
Make a partial update to a specified resource.
Deletes a specified resource
Echoes back a submitted request.
Converts a request connection to a TCP/IP tunnel. Primarily used to support HTTPS communication thru an unencrypted HTTP proxy.

tip.title: Use Methods for their Intended Purpose
tip.para: A developer is not prevented from mis-applying HTTP methods. However, not using resources and methods for their intended and documented purpose will require unique effort on behalf of each client to understand and will be inconsistent with the network infrastructure that has been designed to work with the WWW.

listitem.para: Intended for information retrieval and should not change the state of a resource. Any non-trivial change to a resource by any of these methods is discouraged.
OPTIONS
GET
HEAD
TRACE
Intended for actions that cause side effects. Non-trivial consequences should be limited to the following methods.
DELETE
PUT
POST

tip.title: Abide by Method Safety Rules
tip.para: A developer is not prevented from mis-applying HTTP methods. However, using methods that are expected to be safe (e.g., GET) to make a change to a resource is in violation of the protocol and will make your interface non-uniform.

listitem.para: Multiple invocations of an identical request will result in the same effect. The following methods should be designed to be idempotent.
DELETE
PUT
OPTIONS
GET
HEAD
TRACE
Sending multilpe identical requests may further impact state. Non-idempotent behavior should be limited to the following method.
POST

tip.title: Strive for Idempotence
tip.para: Idempotent methods are much easier to manage. You want to strive for idempotent behavior for both safe and un-safe methods.

note.title: A Resource can be a Member of Multiple Collections
note.para: Collections are just a convenient way to refer to a group of resources all at once. A single resource can be a member of multiple collection resources. For example, a DriverLicense could be a member of the suspended and fines-due collections.

Can reduce client/server round trips
Reduces visibility of resources (by chopping state across multiple representations)
Use should be limited to most important views

Uniform Resource Locator - Identifies how to find a resource (e.g., http://myorg.org/book/isbn/12345/pdf). All URLs are also URIs.
